sections.title: Personal Pronouns & The Verb 'To Be' → Pronombres Personales y el Verbo 'To Be'
sections.objective: Learn personal pronouns and the present simple conjugation of the verb 'to be' (am, is, are).

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: The Verb 'To Be' (Affirmative) → Enfoque gramatical: El verbo 'To Be' (Afirmativo)
grammar.rule: The verb 'to be' describes identity or states. In present simple, it conjugates: I am, You are, He is, She is, It is, We are, They are. We can also use contractions: I'm, You're, He's, She's, It's, We're, They're.
examples: I am a student. / I'm a student.
You are my friend. / You're my friend.
He is a teacher. / He's a teacher.
She is happy. / She's happy.
It is a sunny day. / It's a sunny day.
We are from Costa Rica. / We're from Costa Rica.
They are classmates. / They're classmates.

reading.title: Reading: A New Class → Lectura: Una nueva clase
reading.text: Hello! My name is Ana. I am a student. He is Carlos, he is a student too. We are in the same class. She is Maria, our teacher. She is from Spain. We are excited to learn English. It is a new adventure!

questions.question: Are Ana and Carlos in different classes?
options: No, they are in the same class.
Yes, they are in different classes.
questions.answer: No, they are in the same class.

sections.title: Greetings & 'To Be' in Questions/Negatives → Saludos y 'To Be' en Preguntas/Negativos
sections.objective: Learn common greetings and how to form questions and negative sentences with the verb 'to be'.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: 'To Be' (Negative and Interrogative) → Enfoque gramatical: 'To Be' (Negativo e Interrogativo)
grammar.rule: To make a negative, add 'not' after the verb (am not, is not, are not). Contractions: isn't, aren't. To ask a question, invert the verb and the subject: 'Am I?', 'Is he?', 'Are you?'.
examples: I am not a teacher. (Negative)
He is not from Canada. / He isn't from Canada. (Negative)
They are not late. / They aren't late. (Negative)
Are you a student? Yes, I am. / No, I'm not. (Question/Answer)
Is she from Mexico? Yes, she is. / No, she isn't. (Question/Answer)

reading.title: Reading: First Conversation → Lectura: Primera conversación
reading.text:
Ana: Hello! I'm Ana. Are you new here?
Carlos: Hi Ana! Yes, I am. My name is Carlos. Nice to meet you.
Ana: Nice to meet you too. Welcome! Are you from Colombia?
Carlos: No, I'm not. I'm from Venezuela. And you? Are you from here?
Ana: No, I'm not from here. I'm from Costa Rica. He is Mark. He isn't in our class. He is a teacher.

Is Mark a student?
options: No, he isn't. He is a teacher.
He is not in the class.
questions.answer: No, he isn't. He is a teacher.

options: She isn't from the United States.
She is from the United States.

They aren't from the United States.
listening.answer: She isn't from the United States.

sections.title: Countries, Nationalities & 'Where are you from?' → Países, Nacionalidades y '¿De dónde eres?'
sections.objective: Learn names of countries and nationalities and ask/answer about origin.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Wh- Questions with 'To Be' (Where, What) → Enfoque gramatical: Preguntas 'Wh-' con 'To Be' (Where, What)
grammar.rule: Use 'Where' to ask about place and 'What' to ask about things or information. Structure: Wh-word + 'to be' + subject. Example: 'Where are you from?', 'What is your name?'.
examples: A: Where are you from? B: I am from Mexico.
A: Where is she from? B: She is from Japan.
A: What is your nationality? B: I am Mexican.
A: What is his name? B: His name is Kenji.

reading.title: Reading: International Friends → Lectura: Amigos Internacionales
reading.text: In our English class, we are an international group. I am from Costa Rica, so I am Costa Rican. My friend Carlos is from Venezuela; he is Venezuelan. Our teacher, Maria, is from Spain. She is Spanish. We have other friends too. Kenji is from Japan, so he is Japanese. And Chloe is from France; she is French. We are all from different countries!

questions.question: Is Chloe from Spain?
options: No, she isn't. She is French.
questions.answer: No, she isn't. She is French.

sections.title: Numbers, Age & Phone Numbers → Números, Edad y Números de Teléfono
sections.objective: Learn numbers from 0 to 100, ask for and state age, and exchange phone numbers.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: 'How old...?' and 'What's...?' → Enfoque gramatical: '¿Cuántos años...?' y '¿Cuál es...?'
grammar.rule: To ask for age, use 'How old are you?'. To ask for a phone number, use 'What's your phone number?'. For phone numbers, we say each digit individually. '0' is often pronounced 'oh'.
examples: A: How old are you? B: I am twenty-five years old.
A: How old is he? B: He is thirty.
A: What's your phone number? B: It's 555-018-293. (five-five-five-oh-one-eight-two-nine-three)

reading.title: Reading: Contact Information → Lectura: Información de Contacto
reading.text: To stay in touch, my friends and I share our phone numbers. My number is 310-555-0219. I am twenty-one years old. My friend, Sofia, is twenty-three. Her phone number is 212-555-8740. My other friend, Liam, is twenty. His number is 786-555-1234. It's easy to call them.

sections.title: Possessive Adjectives & The Family → Adjetivos Posesivos y La Familia
sections.objective: Learn to use possessive adjectives (my, your, his, her, its, our, their) and vocabulary for family members.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Possessive Adjectives → Enfoque gramatical: Adjetivos Posesivos
grammar.rule: Possessive adjectives show who owns something. They come before a noun. my, your, his (for a male), her (for a female), its (for a thing/animal), our (for 'we'), their (for 'they').
examples: I am a student. This is my book.
He is a teacher. That is his classroom.
She is a doctor. This is her hospital.
We are a family. This is our house.
They are friends. That is their car.

reading.title: Reading: My Family Photo → Lectura: La Foto de mi Familia
reading.text: This is a photo of my family. My name is Alex. This is my mother, her name is Clara. This is my father, his name is David. They are my parents. I have a sister. Her name is Laura. And I have a brother. His name is Sam. We have a dog. Its name is Rocky. This is our happy family!

speaking.english: Family: mother, father, sister, brother, parents

sections.title: Singular & Plural Nouns / This, That, These, Those → Nombres Singulares y Plurales / This, That, These, Those
sections.objective: Learn to form plural nouns and use demonstrative pronouns to point out objects.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Plurals and Demonstratives → Enfoque gramatical: Plurales y Demostrativos
grammar.rule: To make most nouns plural, add -s (book -> books). For nouns ending in -s, -sh, -ch, -x, -z, add -es (box -> boxes). 'This' (singular) and 'These' (plural) are for things near you. 'That' (singular) and 'Those' (plural) are for things far from you.
examples: This is a pen. These are pens.
That is a window. Those are windows.
This is my book. These are my books.
That is her car. Those are her cars.

reading.title: Reading: In the Classroom → Lectura: En el Salón de Clases
reading.text: I am in my classroom. This is my desk. On my desk, I have one book and two pens. These pens are blue. That is the teacher's desk over there. That desk is big. On her desk, there are many books and papers. Those books are for the class. This classroom is very organized. I like it here.

questions.question: What is 'this' referring to in 'This is my desk'?
What does 'those' refer to in 'Those books are for the class'?
How many pens are on the narrator's desk?

speaking.example: This is my apple. These are my apples.
That is a house. Those are houses.
My keys are here. Your bag is over there.

sections.title: Jobs & 'A/An' → Profesiones y 'A/An'
sections.objective: Learn vocabulary for common jobs and how to use the indefinite articles 'a' and 'an'.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Indefinite Articles 'a' / 'an' → Enfoque gramatical: Artículos Indefinidos 'a' / 'an'
grammar.rule: Use 'a' before a singular noun that starts with a consonant sound (a teacher, a doctor). Use 'an' before a singular noun that starts with a vowel sound (a, e, i, o, u) (an engineer, an artist). We use them to talk about one non-specific thing.
examples: He is a doctor.
She is an architect.
I am a student.
My father is an engineer.
Is she a nurse? Yes, she is.

reading.title: Reading: People in My Neighborhood → Lectura: Gente en mi Vecindario
reading.text: In my neighborhood, people have different jobs. My neighbor, Mr. Smith, is a police officer. His wife is a teacher. Down the street, there is a small clinic. Dr. Evans works there. She is a doctor. My friend's father is an engineer. He builds houses. My aunt is an artist. She paints beautiful pictures. It is an interesting community.

questions.question: Why do we say 'an artist'?
options: Because 'artist' starts with a vowel sound.
Because the artist is a woman.
questions.answer: Because 'artist' starts with a vowel sound.

A: What do you do? B: I'm a chef.

sections.title: Present Simple (I, You, We, They) → Presente Simple (I, You, We, They)
sections.objective: Learn to use the present simple tense for routines and habits with I, you, we, and they.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Present Simple (Affirmative) → Enfoque gramatical: Presente Simple (Afirmativo)
grammar.rule: We use the present simple for habits, routines, and facts. For 'I', 'you', 'we', and 'they', we use the base form of the verb (e.g., 'play', 'eat', 'go').
examples: I live in a big city.
You speak English very well.
We play soccer on Saturdays.
They go to the gym every day.
I work from home.

reading.title: Reading: Our Weekend Routine → Lectura: Nuestra Rutina de Fin de Semana
reading.text: My friends and I have a great weekend routine. On Saturdays, we wake up late. We have breakfast together at a cafe. We talk and laugh a lot. In the afternoon, we go to the park and play frisbee. On Sundays, we relax. I read a book, and my friends watch movies. We love our weekends!

sections.title: Present Simple (He, She, It) → Presente Simple (He, She, It)
sections.objective: Learn to use the present simple tense for the third person singular (he, she, it), including the -s/-es/-ies endings.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: Present Simple (3rd Person Singular) → Enfoque gramatical: Presente Simple (3ª Persona Singular)
grammar.rule: For 'he', 'she', and 'it', we add -s to the base verb (works, eats, plays). If the verb ends in -s, -sh, -ch, -x, -z, add -es (watches, finishes). If it ends in consonant + y, change -y to -ies (study -> studies).
examples: He works at a bank.
She watches a lot of TV.
It rains in the afternoon.
He studies marketing.
She goes to the gym.

reading.title: Reading: My Brother's Daily Routine → Lectura: La Rutina Diaria de mi Hermano
reading.text: My brother, Tom, is a busy person. He wakes up at 6 AM every day. He has a quick breakfast and then he goes to work. He works as a software developer. He finishes work at 5 PM. In the evening, he relaxes. He watches his favorite series on Netflix or he plays the guitar. He loves his routine.

questions.question: What time does Tom wake up?
What does he do in the evening?
options: He watches series or plays the guitar.
questions.answer: He watches series or plays the guitar.

speaking.example: She eats a salad for lunch.
She watches the news in the morning.

sections.title: Present Simple (Questions & Negatives) → Presente Simple (Preguntas y Negativos)
sections.objective: Learn to form questions and negative sentences in the present simple using 'do', 'don't', 'does', and 'doesn't'.

grammar.title: Grammar Focus: do/don't and does/doesn't → Enfoque gramatical: do/don't y does/doesn't
grammar.rule: For negatives, use 'don't' (do not) for I/you/we/they and 'doesn't' (does not) for he/she/it, plus the base verb. For questions, start with 'Do' (for I/you/we/they) or 'Does' (for he/she/it), then the subject and the base verb.
examples: I don't live in a small town.
He doesn't work on weekends.
Do you speak French? Yes, I do. / No, I don't.
Does she like coffee? Yes, she does. / No, she doesn't.
Where do you live?

reading.title: Reading: A Lifestyle Interview → Lectura: Una Entrevista de Estilo de Vida
reading.text:
Interviewer: Hello, Mark. Do you live in the city?
Mark: No, I don't. I live in the suburbs.
Interviewer: And your sister, does she live with you?
Mark: No, she doesn't. She lives in another city. She works as a designer there.
Interviewer: Do you like your job?
Mark: Yes, I do. I work as a journalist. I don't work in an office, I travel a lot.
Interviewer: That sounds exciting! Does your sister like her job?
Mark: Yes, she does. She loves it.
